docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Feature: 

feat(audio): add WASAPI exclusive mode support

- Implement exclusive mode initialization
- Add fallback to shared mode
- Reduce latency from 20ms to 5ms

Closes #42

Bug Fix: 

fix(ui): prevent scrollbar overlap with track controls

The scrollbar was positioned incorrectly when more than 10 tracks
were loaded, causing overlap with mute/solo buttons.

Fixed by adjusting scrollbar position calculation.

Fixes #128

Documentation: 

docs: add performance tuning guide

Created comprehensive guide covering:
- Audio optimization techniques
- UI rendering best practices
- Memory management strategies

Refactoring: 

refactor(core): simplify audio buffer allocation

Replaced dynamic allocation with pre-allocated buffers to improve
real-time safety and reduce latency spikes.

No functional changes.

docs.title: Commit Message Best Practices
docs.text:
Do's: - ✅ Use present tense ("add feature", not "added feature") - ✅ Capitalize first letter of subject - ✅ No period at end of subject line - ✅ Limit subject to 50 characters - ✅ Wrap body at 72 characters - ✅ Separate subject and body with blank line - ✅ Use body to explain what and why, not how

Don'ts: - ❌ Don't use vague messages ("fix bug", "update code") - ❌ Don't commit unrelated changes together - ❌ Don't include WIP (work in progress) commits in main branch

docs.title: Example 1: Function with Good Documentation
docs.text:
/**
 * Calculates the playback position in seconds.
 * 
 * Converts internal sample position to time using the device sample rate.
 * This ensures accurate timing regardless of the sample's original rate.
 * 
 * @return Current playback position in seconds
 * 
 * @note Uses device sample rate, NOT the sample file's rate.
 * @see setPosition() to change playback position
 * 
 * Example:
 * \code
 * double pos = track.getPosition();
 * Log::info("Position: " + std::to_string(pos) + "s");
 * \endcode
 */
double Track::getPosition() const {
    // Use device sample rate for accurate time calculation
    return m_playbackPhase.load() / (double)m_deviceSampleRate;
}

docs.text:
## 🛠️ How to Build

docs.title: Example 3: Inline Code Comment
docs.text:
void TrackManager::processAudio(float* buffer, uint32_t frames, double time) {
    // Clear output buffer
    memset(buffer, 0, frames * 2 * sizeof(float));

    // Mix all tracks into output buffer
    for (auto& track : m_tracks) {
        if (!track->isMuted()) {
            // PERF: Process each track in parallel (future optimization)
            track->processAudio(buffer, frames, time);
        }
    }

    // Apply master volume (range: 0.0 - 2.0, default: 1.0)
    float masterVol = m_masterVolume.load();
    for (uint32_t i = 0; i < frames * 2; ++i) {
        buffer[i] *= masterVol;

        // SAFETY: Clamp to prevent clipping
        buffer[i] = std::clamp(buffer[i], -1.0f, 1.0f);
    }
}

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text: Choose your platform to get started:

docs.title: Windows Quick Start
docs.text:
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/currentsuspect/NOMAD.git
cd NOMAD

# 2. Install Git hooks (recommended)
pwsh -File scripts/install-hooks.ps1

# 3. Configure build (Core-only mode for contributors)
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release

# 4. Build the project
cmake --build build --config Release --parallel

# 5. Run NOMAD
cd build/bin/Release
./NOMAD.exe

docs.title: Linux Quick Start
docs.text:
# 1. Install dependencies
sudo apt update
sudo apt install build-essential cmake git libasound2-dev \
                 libx11-dev libxrandr-dev libxinerama-dev libgl1-mesa-dev

# 2. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/currentsuspect/NOMAD.git
cd NOMAD

# 3. Install Git hooks
bash scripts/install-hooks.sh

# 4. Configure and build
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
cmake --build build --config Release --parallel

# 5. Run NOMAD
./build/bin/NOMAD

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• OS: Windows 10 64-bit (build 1809+), Linux with X11/Wayland, or macOS 10.15+
  • CPU: Intel Core i5 (4th gen) or AMD Ryzen 3
  • RAM: 8 GB
  • GPU: OpenGL 3.3+ compatible with 1 GB VRAM
  • Audio: WASAPI-compatible audio interface (Windows), ALSA (Linux), CoreAudio (macOS)

docs.title: Recommended
docs.text:
• CPU: Intel Core i7/i9 or AMD Ryzen 7/9
  • RAM: 16 GB or more
  • GPU: Dedicated graphics card with 2+ GB VRAM
  • Audio: Low-latency audio interface (ASIO support optional)
  • Storage: SSD for project files and sample libraries

docs.title: 🛠️ Build Modes
docs.text: NOMAD supports different build configurations:

docs.title: Core-Only Mode (Contributors)
docs.text:
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON
Builds only the publicly available source-available modules. Perfect for contributors and learning.

docs.title: Full Build (Internal)
docs.text:
cmake -S . -B build
Includes all modules including private assets. Requires additional permissions.

docs.title: Debug Build
docs.text:
cmake -S . -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug
Includes debug symbols and assertions for development.

docs.title: Release with Debug Info
docs.text:
cmake -S . -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo
Optimized build with debug symbols for profiling.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
CMake cannot find Visual Studio **Solution**: Ensure Visual Studio 2022 is installed with C++ workload: 
# List available generators
cmake --help

# Specify generator explicitly
cmake -G "Visual Studio 17 2022" -A x64 -S . -B build
Missing dependencies on Linux **Solution**: Install all required development packages: 
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install build-essential cmake git \
                 libasound2-dev libx11-dev libxrandr-dev \
                 libxinerama-dev libgl1-mesa-dev

# Check installed packages
dpkg -l | grep -E "(alsa|x11|mesa)"
Git hooks installation fails **Solution**: Ensure PowerShell 7+ is installed and Git hooks directory exists: 
# Check PowerShell version
$PSVersionTable.PSVersion

# Install hooks manually
Copy-Item -Path .githooks\* -Destination .git\hooks\ -Force
Build fails with "private folder present" error **Solution**: This is expected in public CI. For local development: 
# Use NOMAD_CORE_MODE to skip private folders
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON
OpenGL linking errors on Linux **Solution**: Install Mesa OpenGL development libraries: 
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install libgl1-mesa-dev mesa-common-dev

# Fedora/RHEL
sudo dnf install mesa-libGL-devel

# Verify OpenGL installation
glxinfo | grep "OpenGL version"

docs.text:
After building NOMAD, you'll learn:

  • How to launch NOMAD and navigate the UI

  • Saving and loading projects

On first launch, NOMAD will:

  1. Initialize the audio engine (WASAPI/ALSA/CoreAudio)
  2. Load the default theme
  3. Create a new empty project

docs.title: 🖥️ Understanding the Interface
docs.text: NOMAD's interface consists of several key areas:

docs.title: Key UI Components
docs.text:
1. Menu Bar — File operations, preferences, and help
  2. Transport Controls — Play, pause, stop, record
  3. Timeline — Pattern and playlist view with adaptive grid
  4. Mixer — Volume, pan, mute, solo controls (in progress)
  5. Status Bar — CPU usage, audio latency, sample rate

docs.title: Step 1: Configure Audio Settings
docs.text:
1. Open File → Preferences (or press Ctrl+P)
  2. Navigate to Audio Settings
  3. Select your audio interface
  4. Set buffer size (512 samples recommended for ~10ms latency)
  5. Choose sample rate (48000 Hz recommended)
  6. Click Apply

Low Latency Tips

  • Use WASAPI Exclusive mode on Windows for lowest latency
  • Smaller buffer sizes = lower latency but higher CPU usage
  • Start with 512 samples and adjust based on your system

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Pattern
docs.text:
1. Right-click in the timeline to create a new pattern
  2. Name your pattern (e.g., "Kick Pattern")
  3. The pattern editor will open

docs.title: Step 3: Add Samples (Coming Soon)
docs.text:
In Development

Sample manipulation and drag-and-drop features are currently in development. This section will be updated in Q1 2025 when these features are completed.

docs.title: Step 4: Use the Timeline
docs.text:
The timeline in NOMAD is inspired by FL Studio's workflow:

  • Pattern Mode — Create and edit individual patterns
  • Playlist Mode — Arrange patterns on the timeline
  • Adaptive Grid — Automatically adjusts to zoom level
  • Waveform Visualization — See your audio in real-time

docs.title: Step 5: Basic Mixing (In Progress)

docs.title: 🌟 Overview
docs.text:
Muse is Nomad DAW's AI-powered music generation and production assistant. It leverages machine learning models to help producers create, enhance, and refine their music with intelligent suggestions and automation.

Note: Muse is currently in private development and not yet available in the public build. This documentation serves as a reference for future integration.

docs.title: Vision
docs.text: Muse aims to: - Accelerate creativity - Generate musical ideas instantly - Enhance workflow - Automate repetitive production tasks - Improve quality - AI-powered mixing and mastering suggestions - Learn from you - Adapt to your personal style and preferences

docs.title: Status
docs.text: 🚧 Current Status: Private development - Core AI models in training - Integration API being designed - Expected release: TBD

docs.title: 1. Pattern Generation
docs.text:
AI-powered melody and rhythm creation

// Example API (future)
class PatternGenerator {
public:

};

Features: - Style-based generation - Generate in specific genres (EDM, Hip-Hop, Jazz, etc.) - Key and scale awareness - Harmonically correct melodies - Mood control - Happy, sad, energetic, calm, etc. - Complexity adjustment - Simple to complex patterns

Intelligent mixing and mastering suggestions

Features: - Level balancing - Automatic track volume adjustment - EQ suggestions - Frequency-based recommendations - Compression guidance - Dynamic range optimization - Stereo imaging - Spatial placement suggestions

Smart chord and harmony suggestions

docs.title: Application Integration
docs.text:
Where Muse connects to Nomad DAW:

  1. Pattern Editor - Generate patterns on demand
  2. Mixer View - Real-time mix analysis and suggestions
  3. Piano Roll - Chord and melody suggestions while composing
  4. Browser - AI-powered sample search and recommendations
  5. Master Bus - Mastering suggestions and presets

docs.title: API Design Philosophy
docs.text:
Principles for Muse integration:

  • Non-blocking - AI operations run asynchronously
  • Progressive - Partial results shown as they compute
  • Cancellable - User can interrupt long-running operations
  • Cacheable - Results cached to avoid recomputation
  • Transparent - Users understand what AI is doing

docs.title: Example Workflow
docs.text:
// User clicks "Generate Melody" button
musePa tternGen->generateMelodyAsync(
    style,
    key,
    numBars,
    [](const std::vector<Note>& result) {
        // Callback when generation completes
        pianoRoll->setNotes(result);
        pianoRoll->refresh();
    }
);

// Generation runs in background
// User can continue working
// UI updates when complete

docs.title: What is Nomad DAW?
docs.text: Nomad DAW is a modern digital audio workstation built with C++17, featuring: - Ultra-low latency audio engine with WASAPI support - GPU-accelerated custom UI framework (NomadUI) - FL Studio-inspired workflow - Professional-grade audio processing - Planned AI integration (Muse)

docs.title: Who develops Nomad?
docs.text: Nomad is developed by Dylan Makori in Kenya, with contributions from the open-source community. While the source code is publicly visible for transparency, Nomad is proprietary commercial software.

docs.title: Is Nomad free to use?
docs.text: Yes! Nomad Core is free forever. The hybrid model: - ✅ Nomad Core: Completely free - full DAW with all essential features - 💰 Premium Add-ons (future): Muse AI and premium plugins require paid licenses - 👁️ Source code is publicly visible for transparency - 🎓 Student discounts will apply to premium add-ons - 🤝 Contributing to development is free and welcomed

docs.title: What platforms does Nomad support?
docs.text: Current support: - ✅ Windows 10/11 (64-bit) - Primary platform - 🚧 Linux - In development - 📋 macOS - Planned for future

docs.title: Is Nomad open-source?
docs.text:
No. Nomad uses the NSSAL (Nomad Studios Source-Available License) - a source-available license, not open-source. This means: - ✅ Nomad Core is free to use for all purposes - 👁️ You can view and study the source code - 🤝 You can contribute improvements - ❌ You cannot reuse the code in other projects - ❌ You cannot distribute modified versions - 📜 All contributions become property of the project

See License Reference for complete details.

docs.title: How do I build Nomad from source?
docs.text:
Follow our comprehensive Building Guide:

Quick start (Windows): 

git clone https://github.com/currentsuspect/NOMAD.git
cd NOMAD
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
cmake --build build --config Release --parallel

docs.title: What are the build requirements?
docs.text:
All platforms: - CMake 3.15+ - Git 2.30+ - C++17 compatible compiler

Windows: - Visual Studio 2022 with C++ workload - Windows SDK

Linux: - GCC 9+ or Clang 10+ - ALSA, X11, and OpenGL development libraries

docs.title: What is NOMAD_CORE_MODE?
docs.text:
NOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON builds only the public core without premium features. This is required for community contributors since premium modules are in private repositories.

# Public build (community contributors)
cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON

# Full build (requires private repos - internal only)
cmake -S . -B build

docs.title: Build fails with "private folder present" error?
docs.text:
This is expected in public CI. Use NOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON to skip private folders:

cmake -S . -B build -DNOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release

This is necessary because Nomad is commercial software. See Contributing Guide for details.

Private modules (not in public repo): - ❌ Premium plugins and effects - ❌ AI models (Muse internals) - ❌ Licensing system - ❌ Code signing and distribution

docs.title: What audio drivers does Nomad support?
docs.text:
Windows: - ✅ WASAPI (Exclusive and Shared modes) - ✅ DirectSound (fallback) - 📋 ASIO (planned)

Linux: - 🚧 ALSA (in development) - 📋 JACK (planned) - 📋 PulseAudio (planned)

docs.title: What's the typical audio latency?
docs.text:
• WASAPI Exclusive: 5-10ms (best)
  • WASAPI Shared: 10-20ms
  • DirectSound: 20-50ms (fallback)

Latency depends on buffer size, sample rate, and hardware.

docs.title: Does Nomad support plugins?
docs.text: Not yet. Plugin support is planned: - 📋 VST3 hosting - 📋 AU hosting (macOS) - 📋 Native Nomad plugin format

docs.title: How does the UI rendering work?
docs.text:
NomadUI uses a custom immediate-mode rendering system: - OpenGL-based rendering - Adaptive FPS (1-120 FPS based on activity) - GPU-accelerated for smooth 60+ FPS - Cache-friendly widget tree

See Architecture Overview for details.

docs.title: What's the threading model?
docs.text:
Nomad uses multiple threads: - Main Thread: UI and application logic - Audio Thread: Real-time audio processing (lock-free) - Loader Thread: Async file I/O and caching

See Architecture Overview for threading details.

docs.title: Can I use Nomad in my commercial projects?
docs.text:
Yes! Nomad Core is free for all commercial use. This includes: - ✅ Commercial music production - ✅ Client work and studio projects - ✅ Released tracks and albums - ✅ Live performances - ✅ YouTube, streaming, broadcast

Only premium add-ons (Muse AI, premium plugins - future releases) will require paid licenses.

Note: The source code itself is proprietary and cannot be reused in other software projects.

docs.title: What license is Nomad under?
docs.text: Nomad DAW is proprietary commercial software. The source code is visible but not open-source. See License Reference for complete terms.

docs.title: Can I fork Nomad?
docs.text: No. You cannot create forks, derivative works, or distribute modified versions. However: - You can contribute via pull requests - You can suggest features and improvements - You can study the code for educational purposes

docs.title: Can I use Nomad code in my project?
docs.text: No. The code is proprietary and cannot be used in other projects. Any use requires explicit written permission from Dylan Makori.

docs.title: Why is Nomad not open-source?
docs.text:
We chose a proprietary model to: - Fund development - Sustainable business model - Maintain quality - Professional team and support - Provide value - Fair compensation for developers - Competitive edge - Protect innovative features

Source code transparency allows educational use and community contributions while maintaining a viable business.

docs.title: Audio is cutting out or glitching
docs.text:
Possible causes: 1. Buffer size too small - Increase in audio settings 2. CPU overload - Close other applications 3. Wrong driver mode - Try WASAPI Exclusive mode 4. Sample rate mismatch - Check audio settings

Solutions: - Increase buffer size to 512 or 1024 samples - Use WASAPI Exclusive mode for lowest latency - Match sample rates (typically 44100 Hz or 48000 Hz)

docs.title: 📖 Nomad DAW Glossary
docs.text: Comprehensive glossary of technical terms, acronyms, and concepts used in Nomad DAW development.

docs.title: 📋 Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Audio Terms
  • Programming Concepts
  • Nomad-Specific Terms
  • UI/UX Terms
  • Acronyms

docs.title: Audio Buffer
docs.text: A fixed-size block of audio samples processed together. Smaller buffers reduce latency but increase CPU usage. Typical sizes: 128, 256, 512, or 1024 samples.

docs.title: Audio Driver
docs.text: Software interface between application and audio hardware. Examples: WASAPI, ASIO, ALSA, CoreAudio.

docs.title: ASIO (Audio Stream Input/Output)
docs.text: Low-latency audio driver protocol developed by Steinberg. Widely used in professional audio applications (planned for Nomad).

docs.title: Bit Depth
docs.text: Number of bits used to represent each audio sample. Common values: - 16-bit: CD quality - 24-bit: Professional audio - 32-bit float: Internal processing

docs.title: Buffer Size
docs.text: Number of samples in an audio buffer. Affects latency and CPU usage: - Small (64-256): Low latency, high CPU - Medium (256-512): Balanced - Large (512-1024+): High latency, low CPU

docs.title: DAW (Digital Audio Workstation)
docs.text: Software application for recording, editing, mixing, and producing audio content. Nomad is a DAW.

docs.title: Exclusive Mode
docs.text: Audio driver mode with direct hardware access (WASAPI Exclusive). Provides lowest latency but prevents other applications from using audio device.

docs.title: Latency
docs.text: Delay between input and output in audio processing. Lower is better for real-time performance. Measured in milliseconds (ms).

docs.title: Lock-Free
docs.text: Programming technique that avoids mutexes/locks in real-time audio threads. Prevents priority inversion and ensures consistent timing.

docs.title: Sample
docs.text: Single audio value at a specific point in time. At 44100 Hz, there are 44,100 samples per second.

docs.title: Sample Rate
docs.text: Number of samples per second in digital audio. Common rates: - 44100 Hz: CD quality - 48000 Hz: Professional video/audio - 88200 Hz: High resolution - 96000 Hz: Studio quality

docs.title: Shared Mode
docs.text: Audio driver mode that shares hardware access with other applications (WASAPI Shared). Higher latency than Exclusive mode.

docs.title: WASAPI (Windows Audio Session API)
docs.text: Modern audio API for Windows Vista and later. Supports both Exclusive and Shared modes.

docs.title: Waveform
docs.text: Visual representation of audio amplitude over time. Nomad caches waveforms for efficient rendering.

docs.title: Atomic Operation
docs.text: Operation that completes without interruption. Used for lock-free thread communication. Example: std::atomic<bool>.

docs.title: Cache Coherency
docs.text: Ensuring consistent data across CPU caches in multi-threaded programs. Important for audio thread communication.

docs.title: clang-format
docs.text: Tool for automatically formatting C++ code according to a style guide. Nomad uses clang-format for consistent code style.

docs.title: CMake
docs.text: Cross-platform build system generator. Nomad uses CMake for configuring and building the project.

docs.title: Continuation Indent
docs.text: Indentation for line continuations (wrapped lines). Nomad uses 4 spaces.

docs.title: CRTP (Curiously Recurring Template Pattern)
docs.text: C++ template pattern where a derived class passes itself as a template parameter to its base class.

docs.title: Data-Oriented Design
docs.text: Programming approach that organizes data for cache efficiency. Focuses on data layout and access patterns.

docs.title: Immediate Mode
docs.text: UI paradigm where widgets are recreated each frame. Simplifies state management. Used in NomadUI.

docs.title: Lock-Free Queue
docs.text: Thread-safe queue implementation without mutexes. Used for command passing between threads in Nomad.

docs.title: Move Semantics
docs.text: C++11 feature for transferring ownership of resources without copying. Uses std::move().

docs.title: RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization)
docs.text: C++ programming idiom where resource lifetime is tied to object lifetime. Resources released automatically in destructor.

docs.title: Real-Time
docs.text: Requirement that operations complete within strict time constraints. Audio processing must be real-time to avoid glitches.

docs.title: Ring Buffer
docs.text: Circular buffer used for lock-free data transfer between threads. Fixed size, overwrites oldest data when full.

docs.title: Smart Pointer
docs.text: C++ object that automatically manages memory. Types: - std::unique_ptr: Exclusive ownership - std::shared_ptr: Shared ownership - std::weak_ptr: Non-owning reference

docs.title: Template
docs.text: C++ feature for generic programming. Allows functions and classes to work with any type.

docs.title: Thread Safety
docs.text: Property where code can be safely called from multiple threads without race conditions or data corruption.

docs.title: Adaptive FPS
docs.text: NomadUI feature that dynamically adjusts frame rate (1-120 FPS) based on user activity to conserve CPU.

docs.title: Core Mode
docs.text: Build configuration (NOMAD_CORE_MODE=ON) that excludes private/premium features. Required for public contributors.

docs.title: Muse
docs.text: Nomad's AI-powered music generation and production assistant (in private development).

docs.title: NomadAudio
docs.text: Nomad's audio engine module responsible for playback, recording, and processing.

docs.title: NomadCore
docs.text: Foundation module providing platform abstraction, utilities, and common types.

docs.title: NomadPlat
docs.text: Platform-specific implementations for Windows, Linux, and macOS.

docs.title: NomadUI
docs.text: Custom GPU-accelerated UI framework built specifically for Nomad DAW.

docs.title: Premium Features
docs.text: Proprietary features available only in paid version (AI models, advanced effects, licensing).

docs.title: Public Build
docs.text: Build from public repository with core features only. No premium features or private assets.

docs.title: Sample Clip
docs.text: Visual representation of an audio sample on the timeline. Can be moved, resized, and edited.

docs.title: Track Manager
docs.text: Component that manages multiple audio tracks, playback state, and mixing.

docs.title: Transport Bar
docs.text: UI component containing playback controls (play, pause, stop, record).

docs.title: Component
docs.text: Self-contained UI element with its own rendering and event handling. Examples: button, slider, dropdown.

docs.title: Coordinate System
docs.text: System for positioning UI elements. NomadUI uses hierarchical coordinates (parent-relative).

docs.title: Culling
docs.text: Optimization technique that skips rendering elements outside visible area. Nomad uses 200px culling padding.

docs.title: Event Handling
docs.text: Process of responding to user input (mouse, keyboard). Events propagate through widget hierarchy.

docs.title: Layout Engine
docs.text: System for automatically positioning and sizing UI elements based on constraints.

docs.title: OpenGL
docs.text: Cross-platform graphics API used by NomadUI for GPU-accelerated rendering.

docs.title: Playhead
docs.text: Vertical line indicator showing current playback position on the timeline.

docs.title: Render Loop
docs.text: Continuous cycle that updates and draws UI. Nomad's adaptive FPS adjusts loop frequency.

docs.title: Ruler
docs.text: UI component showing time divisions (bars, beats) on the timeline.

docs.title: Timeline
docs.text: Horizontal representation of time where audio clips are arranged and edited.

docs.title: Viewport
docs.text: Visible portion of a larger scrollable area. Timeline viewport shows part of full project.

docs.title: Widget
docs.text: Basic UI element (button, slider, label). Building block of the UI system.

docs.title: Z-Order
docs.text: Rendering order of overlapping UI elements. Higher z-order renders on top.

docs.title: ALSA
docs.text: Advanced Linux Sound Architecture - Linux audio driver system.

docs.title: API
docs.text: Application Programming Interface - Set of functions and types for using a library or system.

docs.title: BPM
docs.text: Beats Per Minute - Tempo measurement in music.

docs.title: CI/CD
docs.text: Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment - Automated testing and deployment.

docs.title: CLA
docs.text: Contributor License Agreement - Legal agreement for code contributions.

docs.title: CPU
docs.text: Central Processing Unit - Main processor in a computer.

docs.title: DAW
docs.text: Digital Audio Workstation - Software for audio production.

docs.title: DPI
docs.text: Dots Per Inch - Display resolution measurement.

docs.title: DSP
docs.text: Digital Signal Processing - Mathematical manipulation of signals.

docs.title: FPS
docs.text: Frames Per Second - Refresh rate of visual display.

docs.title: GPU
docs.text: Graphics Processing Unit - Specialized processor for graphics rendering.

docs.title: GUI
docs.text: Graphical User Interface - Visual interface for interacting with software.

docs.title: IDE
docs.text: Integrated Development Environment - Software for code editing and debugging (e.g., Visual Studio).

docs.title: I/O
docs.text: Input/Output - Data transfer between system and external devices.

docs.title: JUCE
docs.text: Jules' Utility Class Extensions - C++ framework for audio applications (not used in Nomad, but referenced).

docs.title: MIDI
docs.text: Musical Instrument Digital Interface - Protocol for communicating musical data (planned for Nomad).

docs.title: ML
docs.text: Machine Learning - AI technique used in Muse.

docs.title: MSVC
docs.text: Microsoft Visual C++ - Microsoft's C++ compiler.

docs.title: PR
docs.text: Pull Request - Proposed code changes on GitHub.

docs.title: RAII
docs.text: Resource Acquisition Is Initialization - C++ programming idiom.

docs.title: RAM
docs.text: Random Access Memory - Computer memory for active data.

docs.title: SDK
docs.text: Software Development Kit - Tools and libraries for development.

docs.title: SoA
docs.text: Struct of Arrays - Data layout technique for performance.

docs.title: UI
docs.text: User Interface - Visual elements for user interaction.

docs.title: UX
docs.text: User Experience - Overall experience of using software.

docs.title: VST
docs.text: Virtual Studio Technology - Plugin format for audio effects and instruments (planned for Nomad).

docs.title: WASAPI
docs.text: Windows Audio Session API - Modern Windows audio API.

docs.title: Branching Strategy
docs.text: Git workflow defining how branches are created, named, and merged. See Contributing Guide.

docs.title: Code Review
docs.text: Process of examining code changes before merging. Ensures quality and maintainability.

docs.title: Commit Message
docs.text: Description of changes in a Git commit. Nomad uses conventional commit format (feat:, fix:, etc.).

docs.title: Dependency Injection
docs.text: Design pattern where dependencies are provided to an object rather than created internally.

docs.title: Git Hook
docs.text: Script that runs automatically on Git events (e.g., pre-commit). Nomad uses hooks for code formatting.

docs.title: Integration Testing
docs.text: Testing multiple components together to verify they work correctly as a system.

docs.title: Refactoring
docs.text: Restructuring code without changing its external behavior. Improves maintainability.

docs.title: Regression
docs.text: Bug that reappears after being fixed, or new bug introduced by changes.

docs.title: Technical Debt
docs.text: Accumulated cost of suboptimal design decisions. Paid back through refactoring.

docs.title: Unit Test
docs.text: Test that verifies a single component in isolation. Helps catch bugs early.

docs.title: 🌟 Vision
docs.text:
Mission: Build a professional digital audio workstation that combines: - Intuitive workflow inspired by FL Studio - Professional audio quality with ultra-low latency - AI-powered assistance to enhance creativity - Modern architecture built with C++17

Core Values: - 🎯 Quality over quantity - Every feature polished and reliable - ⚡ Performance first - Real-time audio without compromise - 🎨 User-centric design - Intuitive and beautiful interface - 🤝 Community-driven - Transparent development with user feedback

docs.title: ✅ What Works Today
docs.text:
Audio Engine (90% complete) - ✅ WASAPI integration (Exclusive/Shared modes) - ✅ Multi-track audio playback - ✅ Sample-accurate timing - ✅ Lock-free audio thread - ✅ Waveform caching (4096 samples) - ✅ 64-bit floating-point processing

User Interface (75% complete) - ✅ Custom NomadUI framework - ✅ OpenGL rendering with adaptive FPS - ✅ FL Studio-style timeline - ✅ Transport controls (play, pause, stop) - ✅ File browser with preview - ✅ Audio device selection - ✅ Zoom and scroll

Platform Support (70% complete) - ✅ Windows 10/11 (64-bit) - 🚧 Linux (in progress) - 📋 macOS (planned)
